rdf:Alt.rdf:li: {\rtf1 (upbeat music)}
{\rtf1 All right, so this lab, in\par my opinion, might be one}
{\rtf1 of the most important\par labs of this entire class.}
{\rtf1 Now, nope, I didn't say the coolest,}
{\rtf1 or the sexiest, or the most fun.}
{\rtf1 It's not going to be this most fun lab.}
{\rtf1 It's going to be one\par of the most important.}
{\rtf1 This lab deals with\par analyzing a data source}
{\rtf1 to see what you can cut out,}
{\rtf1 what do you not need in your environment.}
{\rtf1 This is going to be based on Windows Logs.}
{\rtf1 It assumes that we\par brought in Windows Logs.}
{\rtf1 We brought in pretty much\par everything on the box,}
{\rtf1 and we're analyzing it to see,}
{\rtf1 do I need everything in here?}
{\rtf1 And what's going to happen\par is you're going to start}
{\rtf1 with a ton of logs, and\par as we go through this,}
{\rtf1 I'm going to call out certain logs}
{\rtf1 and that do we really need those?}
{\rtf1 And we're going to keep track\par of how many logs we started with}
{\rtf1 and what we end up with,}
{\rtf1 and what we're going to find\par out is we can actually get rid}
{\rtf1 of a lot of logs without\par losing tactical capabilities.}
{\rtf1 So this is one of the most\par important labs of 555,}
{\rtf1 because if you bring in new data sources,}
{\rtf1 and you apply the same process\par we do in this, onto the logs,}
{\rtf1 you'll be able to retain much more data,}
{\rtf1 and you'll be able to run faster searches,}
{\rtf1 because you're not storing everything.}
{\rtf1 I'm not saying get rid of everything.}
{\rtf1 I'm saying get rid of\par the stuff you don't need.}
{\rtf1 Like, we're going to analyze it,}
{\rtf1 and if you literally don't need it,}
{\rtf1 we can get rid of it.}
{\rtf1 This works with compliance,\par with everything.}
{\rtf1 This is what you want to get to.}
{\rtf1 So let's go ahead and do this.}
{\rtf1 So in this scenario, we're\par going to look for a few things.}
{\rtf1 What is the most frequent of NID?}
{\rtf1 What is it, do we care?}
{\rtf1 Filter out Windows Firewall events.}
{\rtf1 Ideally, we should really\par get our firewall logs tuned,}
{\rtf1 so that they're not constantly triggering.}
{\rtf1 And we should be able to get rid of that.}
{\rtf1 We've got Microsoft system\par eternal, Sysmon on these boxes.}
{\rtf1 If we're collecting those\par logs, do we need all of them?}
{\rtf1 Is there stuff we don't\par want, and if so, where do you}
{\rtf1 apply those filters,\par what about log on events?}
{\rtf1 How many of them, do we need all of them?}
{\rtf1 What does it look like?}
{\rtf1 And then just other information,}
{\rtf1 so let's go ahead and just\par start diving into this.}
{\rtf1 For this, we're going to be\par looking at the lab three one}
{\rtf1 dashboard, so I'm going to flip\par to dashboards, lab three one,}
{\rtf1 here we go, we're going to\par start with this dashboard.}
{\rtf1 Now know, there's 29,019 logs in this lab,}
{\rtf1 for the time we're selected on.}
{\rtf1 What we're going to do is\par start going through these.}
{\rtf1 Specifically, the first\par question was pertaining to,}
{\rtf1 what's your highest event source?}
{\rtf1 Well, if we look at this, it's 5156.}
{\rtf1 Well, what is that?}
{\rtf1 If you click on it, 21,000,\par a vast majority of the logs,}
{\rtf1 are coming from 5156, which\par is the filtering platform}
{\rtf1 connection, specifically\par its Firewall logs,}
{\rtf1 about permitting connections,\par so it's allowing something,}
{\rtf1 and that is generating a ton of logs,}
{\rtf1 'cause every network\par connection that's allowed,}
{\rtf1 it's generating an event, so\par we may not want to collect}
{\rtf1 all the allow connections,\par 'cause that might preventing}
{\rtf1 us from collecting Firewall\par logs to begin with.}
{\rtf1 Alright, well let's exclude that.}
{\rtf1 Maybe you want to\par collect those, maybe not,}
{\rtf1 but if we didn't collect\par those, that's a large chunk}
{\rtf1 of these logs, alright let's keep going.}
{\rtf1 Well, when we do that,\par Firewall logs are still}
{\rtf1 in this 74 hundred remaining logs,}
{\rtf1 so I'm just curious,\par let's zoom in on that,}
{\rtf1 and see what other\par Firewall logs there are.}
{\rtf1 We see that there are\par three different events,}
{\rtf1 and if we were to start\par looking through these,}
{\rtf1 whether we click on them\par or just browse down,}
{\rtf1 5158 is allowed an application to bind,}
{\rtf1 so it's what executables\par are listening on ports.}
{\rtf1 5154, we as permitted an\par application to listen on a port,}
{\rtf1 so very similar, and the other one,}
{\rtf1 which would have been the\par 5157, I'm just going to cheat,}
{\rtf1 and jump right to 'em,\par block the connection,}
{\rtf1 and in this case if we look at these,}
{\rtf1 block, block, block, SVC host,\par and we even see N.X. log,}
{\rtf1 which is the log agent used for this lab,}
{\rtf1 so if somewhere in there is\par actually blocking itself.}
{\rtf1 It's things we want to fix,\par which would prevent the logs}
{\rtf1 from coming in, so we have\par multiple of these in here.}
{\rtf1 Let me get rid of this, alright.}
{\rtf1 So we see a lot of\par these events are related}
{\rtf1 to Firewall events, alright.}
{\rtf1 If we were to get rid of the\par Firewall events for a second,}
{\rtf1 just look at everything else,}
{\rtf1 so I'm just going to get rid of that.}
{\rtf1 We have, wait for the 67}
{\rtf1 hundredish logs left,}
{\rtf1 and we look at these, we\par are saying object access,}
{\rtf1 process create, network\par connection, process access.}
{\rtf1 If we dive into these,\par what I want to look at now}
{\rtf1 are the top two remaining leftovers,}
{\rtf1 so (mumbles) 4656 and one.}
{\rtf1 If I look at 4656,}
{\rtf1 these are audit object access,}
{\rtf1 so these are going to show us things like,}
{\rtf1 a handle to an object was\par requested, well what is that?}
{\rtf1 We'll drill down into that and\par it's basically just saying,}
{\rtf1 a plug-in-place security\par object was interacted with,}
{\rtf1 and if you kept, keep looking at these,}
{\rtf1 it's just a bunch of specific information,}
{\rtf1 that's not always very helpful,}
{\rtf1 and yet this is a high volume log,}
{\rtf1 so these handles to objects\par may or may not be necessary.}
{\rtf1 You could shut them off\par entirely with an audit policy,}
{\rtf1 or you could selectively only\par collect things you care about}
{\rtf1 with a log agent, that's\par just some odd data.}
{\rtf1 So alright, let's get\par rid of that for a second.}
{\rtf1 Let's look at event I.D. one,\par if we look at event I.D. one,}
{\rtf1 which is the second highest remaining}
{\rtf1 event I.D. at this point,\par their process creation events,}
{\rtf1 specifically it's Sysmon.}
{\rtf1 Go down here.}
{\rtf1 Let's do that again.}
{\rtf1 There we go, there we go, much better.}
{\rtf1 I didn't hit search.}
{\rtf1 Alright, so here we go, process creation.}
{\rtf1 So these are Sysmon logs,\par we're seeing CMDDXC,}
{\rtf1 running a VMR tool script.}
{\rtf1 Let's keep going, lot of those apparently.}
{\rtf1 Search protocol host.}
{\rtf1 So basically, this box is logging}
{\rtf1 all processes being created.}
{\rtf1 It's the default Sysmon behavior.}
{\rtf1 It's logging basically everything.}
{\rtf1 That's too much data, a\par lot of these are normal.}
{\rtf1 VMR tools is on the box, so\par it's doing VMR processes.}
{\rtf1 I don't necessarily\par need to know about stuff}
{\rtf1 I'm expecting to see, so\par some of what I could do,}
{\rtf1 is tune those and minimize them,}
{\rtf1 so if we're looking at Sysmon\par logs, what can I minimize,}
{\rtf1 if anything, so if I get rid\par of, let's, let's zoom in on}
{\rtf1 Sysmon here for a second.}
{\rtf1 And I'm going to get\par rid of event I.D. one.}
{\rtf1 Move that search, so there's\par little shy of 2,000 events}
{\rtf1 related to Sysmon in this time period.}
{\rtf1 We've got process creation,\par which is the majority}
{\rtf1 network connections, process accessed,}
{\rtf1 and a few other ones.}
{\rtf1 So in here, if I want to\par figure out how I can limit}
{\rtf1 Sysmon data, so that I'm only seeing,}
{\rtf1 hopefully abnormal logs\par rather than normal logs,}
{\rtf1 some of the things I could do is ignore}
{\rtf1 processes running from known directories.}
{\rtf1 See Windows System 32, see program files,}
{\rtf1 see program files X86.}
{\rtf1 Now, I get it, malware can get\par themselves in those locations}
{\rtf1 and it can run, I totally get that.}
{\rtf1 But usually what happens\par is they get downloaded}
{\rtf1 to a user directory or a temp directory,}
{\rtf1 something that is writable\par by a standard user.}
{\rtf1 They compromise the box and\par then they try to move around,}
{\rtf1 but a lot of times, if\par they don't have permission}
{\rtf1 to these other folders, they won't work,}
{\rtf1 or even if it does, they\par start somewhere else,}
{\rtf1 in which case excluding these\par still gives me a good chance}
{\rtf1 at catching what's going on.}
{\rtf1 Let me go ahead and search for this.}
{\rtf1 So in this case, I'm going\par to go from 1852 down to,}
{\rtf1 (mouse clicks)}
{\rtf1 Make sure I got that right.}
{\rtf1 (mouse clicks)}
{\rtf1 Let me update my search here a little bit.}
{\rtf1 (mouse clicks)}
{\rtf1 (mumbles) I got to type\par all my search, here we go.}
{\rtf1 Do that again, to 257, so\par significantly less data.}
{\rtf1 Just by removing a lot\par of the areas that I'm,}
{\rtf1 I expect to see normal applications run,}
{\rtf1 that have been installed\par by an administrator.}
{\rtf1 Now, if you were to make this change,}
{\rtf1 yes, you could make it at a log agent,}
{\rtf1 but the best spot would\par be to tune Sysmon itself,}
{\rtf1 to not log for these directories,}
{\rtf1 or to only log in user LAN.}
{\rtf1 If you're wanting to look\par for some really good Sysmon}
{\rtf1 log collection and configuration files,}
{\rtf1 look for swift on security,\par it's a get hub repo for Sysmon,}
{\rtf1 well swift on security\par has multiple things,}
{\rtf1 but Google swift on\par security, Sysmon, and there's}
{\rtf1 a get hub repo with a\par sample configuration file.}
{\rtf1 It's a really good starter,\par for minimizing how much logs}
{\rtf1 you'll generate, while\par still keeping the key things}
{\rtf1 you need to catch the bad guys,}
{\rtf1 so that's something we could do here.}
{\rtf1 Alright, let's keep going,\par so let's, remove out,}
{\rtf1 Sysmon data here for a\par second, and let's flip over}
{\rtf1 and look at log on events,\par so I'm going to remove}
{\rtf1 all of the search here\par for a second, remove that.}
{\rtf1 (mouse clicks)}
{\rtf1 And remove these, then I'm\par going to search for only log on}
{\rtf1 events, there's 382 log on events,}
{\rtf1 but if you look at these,}
{\rtf1 a lot of these are from DC\par oh one, system, IT oh one,}
{\rtf1 IT oh two, IT oh three,\par now notice all of these end}
{\rtf1 with a dollar sign, which means\par they're computer accounts.}
{\rtf1 These are the computer\par accounts themselves,}
{\rtf1 authenticating the actor directory.}
{\rtf1 Just completely normal,\par but it's generating}
{\rtf1 a lot of logs in this, so one\par of the things I'm going to do}
{\rtf1 is I had a log stash filter in here,}
{\rtf1 that when the system\par log came in, if it was a}
{\rtf1 vanity 4624, if the user\par field ended in a dollar sign,}
{\rtf1 I added a tag of machine,}
{\rtf1 and that's because it's a computer,}
{\rtf1 not an actual user, and\par windows environment,}
{\rtf1 if it end, a user ends in a dollar sign,}
{\rtf1 that's the computer's user account.}
{\rtf1 Now if I exclude the computers,}
{\rtf1 I'll go from 382 to 139,}
{\rtf1 so I almost remove two\par thirds of my log on events}
{\rtf1 right there, in a production environment,}
{\rtf1 you want log on events\par and log on failures.}
{\rtf1 You may not need them\par for computer accounts,}
{\rtf1 because it's all day long,\par non-stop, high volume,}
{\rtf1 and it's not that great of a detect.}
{\rtf1 Use it real users, yes,\par computer accounts, not so much.}
{\rtf1 Maybe failed ones, log on\par success, that should be happening}
{\rtf1 all the time, so that's\par something you could filter out.}
{\rtf1 Now, the other thing is we\par have these built-in service}
{\rtf1 accounts, we still have system,\par we have anonymous log-on,}
{\rtf1 local service, network\par service, you could also exclude}
{\rtf1 some of those, that would\par get us down to about 58,}
{\rtf1 and really I could get\par rid of anonymous log-on,}
{\rtf1 which would bring me down to 53.}
{\rtf1 Now, realistically I tend to\par want to keep some of these,}
{\rtf1 'cause like system, that's\par a special built-in account,}
{\rtf1 but malware often will privilege\par escalate and become system,}
{\rtf1 and I want to see that kind of activity.}
{\rtf1 I'm more concerned with the\par computer, the machine account,}
{\rtf1 than I am these, a actual service account,}
{\rtf1 you may not need it, but then again,}
{\rtf1 you might still want\par those, it's just kind of,}
{\rtf1 get the process, you\par decide, I'm just giving you}
{\rtf1 some options going on here, alright.}
{\rtf1 So, if we do that, we're down to 53 logs,}
{\rtf1 and there's other things, I want\par to flip over here real quick.}
{\rtf1 There was a three one\par with filters applied.}
{\rtf1 This would show, basically\par if we got rid of things,}
{\rtf1 like the C program files for Sysmon,}
{\rtf1 we got rid of some of the Firewall logs.}
{\rtf1 We got rid of the special log-on events.}
{\rtf1 If we did that, I theoretically\par could get my windows logs}
{\rtf1 down to about 4,077,\par compared to the original,}
{\rtf1 There we go.}
{\rtf1 29,019, which means I\par can go farther than 80%,}
{\rtf1 almost 90% lock reduction, with filters.}
{\rtf1 Now, in many organizations,\par that might be too aggressive,}
{\rtf1 but you need to find\par somewhere in the middle here,}
{\rtf1 that's your sweet-spot,\par you don't need everything,}
{\rtf1 so what, based on what we did in this lab,}
{\rtf1 the process behind is what\par matters, what can you get rid of?}
{\rtf1 In every data source,\par especially the large ones,}
{\rtf1 or new ones, or really even\par ongoing, apply the logic}
{\rtf1 and process behind this\par lab, go lean and mean,}
{\rtf1 because that's going to help\par you better do detection.}
{\rtf1 You're spending less time\par going through worthless logs.}
{\rtf1 It's faster and you can do more things.}
{\rtf1 This is one of the most important labs.}
{\rtf1 Again, not the most fun,\par but highly important.}
